title: Lucas Kook
text:
News

New preprint: “Model-based causal feature selection for general response types” in collaboration with Sorawit Saengkyongam, Anton Rask Lundborg, Torsten Hothorn and Jonas Peters. Software implementing our method is available as an R package (tramicp on GitHub and on CRAN).
I acquired a postdoctoral mobility grant from the Swiss National Science Foundation for my proposal on Distributional Instrumental Variables Estimation (DIVE). During the first year of the fellowship, I will be working with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters at the University of Copenhagen, starting March 2023.
I succesfully defended my PhD thesis titled “Deep Learning and Causal Inference with Transformation Models” on February 8, 2023.
New preprint: “Estimating Conditional Distributions with Neural Networks using R package deeptrafo” with software available on CRAN

title: Software
text:
Kook L (2023). “tramicp: Model-Based Causal Feature Selection for General Response Types.” R package available on GitHub and on CRAN.
Kook L, Baumann PFM, Rügamer D (2022). “deeptrafo: Fitting Deep Conditional Transformation Models.” R package available on CRAN.
Kook L, Siegfried S, Hothorn T (2022). “tramvs: Optimal Subset Selection for Transformation Models.” R package available on CRAN.
Rügamer D, Pfisterer F, Kook L, Baumann P, Kolb C (2022). “deepregression: Fitting Deep Distributional Regressions.” R package available on CRAN.
Kook L, Tamasi B, Siegfried S, Pawel S, Hothorn T (2021). “tramnet: Penalized Transformation Models.” R package available on CRAN.
Kook L, Wolski W (2021). “prora: ORA, sigORA and GSEA Functionalities for Proteomic Data.” R package available on GitHub.

title: About me
text: I am currently a postdoctoral researcher in statistics and causal inference at the Copenhagen Causality Lab. Together with Niklas Pfister and Jonas Peters, I work at the intersection of distributional regression and causal inference with a focus on biomedical applications. Recently, I finished my PhD at the University of Zurich under the supervision of Beate Sick and Torsten Hothorn. My PhD research focused on combining distributional regression models with deep learning approaches and causal inference to improve treatment decisions for acute ischemic stroke patients.
